fields.label_text:
British Galleries:
Slipware beer mugs and jugs were made at Harlow in Essex throughout the 17th century. Their only decoration was stylised ornament in white slip and a limited range of inscriptions, usually pious. It is not certain whether this mug was made as Royalist propaganda just before the Civil War, or after the Restoration of Charles II in 1660.

fields.descriptive_line: Slipware mug inscribed, 'OBEAY THE KING', made and decorated in Harlow, Essex, about 1660.
fields.physical_description: Red earthenware lead-glazed barrel-shaped mug with one handle. Decorated with white trailed slip, including the inscription, 'OBEAY THE KING'.
fields.dimensions: Height: 14.8 cm max, Width: 13.5 cm including handle, Diameter: 10.5 cm
fields.materials_techniques: Red earthenware, with decoration in white trailed clay slip under a lead glaze
fields.label:
British Galleries:
Slipware beer mugs and jugs were made at Harlow in Essex throughout the 17th century. Their only decoration was stylised ornament in white slip and a limited range of inscriptions, usually pious. It is not certain whether this mug was made as Royalist propaganda just before the Civil War, or after the Restoration of Charles II in 1660. [27/03/2003]
fields.public_access_description:
Object Type
After years of copying German stoneware forms, in the 17th century the potters of Harlow and the Surrey/Hampshire borders began to adopt the barrel shape for their for beer mugs. Even the Southwark-based immigrants from The Netherlands adopted this form for their painted delftware mugs; it was simple to make in thick earthenware and provided a large surface area for decoration. As they had no colours available apart from red and white clays, the slipware potters developed simple designs of dots, dashes, zigzags and scrolls.

Time
As it was considered nutritious, beer was not among the luxuries despised by the Puritans. However, such typical inscriptions as 'OBEAY GODS WORD', 'FEAR THE LORD THE GOD' and 'REMEMBER THY END TRULY' found on these mugs were certainly not designed to aid conviviality.

Places
Since potters working in London were disadvantaged by having to import all their materials, local country potteries with suitable clay supplied the capital with cheap utilitarian wares. The fine white clays of the Surrey/Hampshire borders were suitable for drinking and cooking vessels, while the more common red clays were used for coarser slipwares. Until the kilns at Harlow were discovered and excavated, these brash red and white slipwares, found in large quantities in London, were called 'Metropolitan'.
fields.credit: Lent by the Trustees of the British Museum
